items.description: Analyze repository structure and define project scope for minimal gravity simulation
items.acceptance_criteria: Written document (ANALYSIS.md) listing: (1) all existing repo files and directories with purposes, (2) chosen programming language with justification, (3) definition of 'minimal' scope — which gravitational physics to include (Newtonian point-mass only vs. extensions), target particle counts, and output format
items.notes: ANALYSIS.md created with repo structure, Python 3.10 justification, and minimal scope definition (Newtonian point-mass, 2D, N up to 1000, 4 integrators)

items.description: Conduct literature review on N-body gravitational simulation methods via web search
items.acceptance_criteria: Web search performed for at least 3 distinct query topics: (1) N-body gravitational simulation algorithms, (2) symplectic integrators for orbital mechanics, (3) efficient force computation methods (Barnes-Hut, FMM). Summary of findings written in ANALYSIS.md with at least 5 key papers identified by title and authors
items.notes: Literature review completed: 3 web search topics (N-body algorithms, symplectic integrators, Barnes-Hut/FMM). 8 key papers identified in ANALYSIS.md section 4. Sources added to sources.bib.

items.description: Survey existing open-source gravity simulation codebases and libraries
items.acceptance_criteria: Web search performed for open-source N-body simulators (e.g., REBOUND, Gadget, nbody6). At least 4 existing codebases identified with notes on: language, integration method, force algorithm, and license. Comparison table added to ANALYSIS.md
items.notes: Surveyed 6 codebases: REBOUND, Gadget-2, NBODY6++GPU, GravHopper, galpy, pynbody. Comparison table added to ANALYSIS.md section 5.

items.description: Create and populate sources.bib with BibTeX entries for all consulted references
items.acceptance_criteria: File sources.bib exists in repo root with valid BibTeX entries. At least 10 relevant papers/references cited, covering: gravitational N-body methods, numerical integration schemes (Verlet, leapfrog, symplectic), force computation algorithms, and energy conservation analysis. Each entry has complete author, title, year, and venue fields
items.notes: sources.bib has 17 BibTeX entries covering N-body methods (Dehnen, Trenti, Aarseth), integrators (Verlet, Yoshida, Stormer, Hairer), force algorithms (Barnes-Hut, Greengard-Rokhlin), codebases (REBOUND, Gadget, NBODY6, GravHopper), and energy conservation (Hairer et al 2006, Hernandez 2015).

items.description: Define mathematical formulation of the Newtonian gravitational N-body problem
items.acceptance_criteria: ANALYSIS.md contains: (1) Newton's law of universal gravitation equation, (2) equations of motion for N point masses, (3) definitions of gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy, (4) statement of total energy conservation property, (5) identification of the softening parameter and its role in avoiding singularities
items.notes: ANALYSIS.md section 6 contains: Newton gravitation law, N-body equations of motion, PE and KE definitions, energy conservation property, and softening parameter with role explained.

items.description: Survey and compare numerical integration methods applicable to gravity simulation
items.acceptance_criteria: ANALYSIS.md contains comparison of at least 4 integration methods: Forward Euler, Velocity Verlet, Leapfrog, and one higher-order method (e.g., RK4 or Yoshida 4th-order). Each method described with: order of accuracy, symplectic property (yes/no), time-reversibility, and expected energy drift behavior. Recommended method for baseline identified with justification citing sources.bib
items.notes: ANALYSIS.md section 7 compares 4 integrators (Forward Euler, Velocity Verlet, Leapfrog, Yoshida 4th-order) with order, symplecticity, time-reversibility, energy drift behavior. Velocity Verlet recommended as baseline with citations.

items.description: Implement particle/body data structure and simulation state representation
items.acceptance_criteria: Source file (e.g., gravity_sim.py or gravity_sim.js) exists with: (1) data structure for a body with mass, position (2D or 3D vector), and velocity vector, (2) function to initialize N bodies with given parameters, (3) function to initialize a simple 2-body system with known Keplerian orbit parameters. Unit test confirming initialization produces correct state
items.notes: gravity_sim.py created with: init_bodies(), init_circular_binary(), init_random_bodies(). Unit test: COM at origin, total momentum zero, energies computed correctly.

items.description: Implement direct-summation O(N^2) pairwise gravitational force computation
items.acceptance_criteria: Function that computes gravitational acceleration on each body from all other bodies using direct pairwise summation. Includes softening parameter (default epsilon > 0). Unit test: for 2 equal masses separated by distance d, computed force magnitude equals G*m^2/(d^2 + epsilon^2). Newton's third law verified (equal and opposite forces)
items.notes: compute_accelerations() with softening verified: force magnitude G*m/(d^2+eps^2)^{3/2}*d matches expected, Newton 3rd law holds, y-components zero for x-aligned pair.

items.description: Implement Forward Euler integration as the initial baseline integrator
items.acceptance_criteria: Function that advances simulation state by one time step dt using Forward Euler (x += v*dt, v += a*dt). Integration loop that runs for N_steps. Test: circular 2-body orbit with dt=0.001 runs for 100 steps without NaN or overflow. Energy measured at start and end
items.notes: step_euler() tested: 100 steps with dt=0.001 on circular binary, no NaN/overflow. Relative energy error 4e-4 after 100 steps (linear drift as expected).

items.description: Implement energy computation for conservation tracking
items.acceptance_criteria: Functions to compute: (1) total kinetic energy (sum of 0.5*m*v^2), (2) total gravitational potential energy (sum of -G*m_i*m_j/r_ij for all pairs), (3) total energy (KE + PE). Unit test: for a known 2-body configuration, computed energies match hand-calculated values to within 1e-10 relative error
items.notes: KE, PE, and total energy functions verified against hand calculations for known 2-body config. All relative errors < 1e-14 (effectively zero).

items.description: Create test harness with known analytical solutions for validation
items.acceptance_criteria: Test script that: (1) sets up a circular 2-body Keplerian orbit with known period T, (2) runs simulation for exactly 1 orbital period, (3) measures position error (distance from expected return position), (4) measures relative energy error |dE/E0|. Baseline Euler results recorded in results/ directory as JSON. Position error and energy error values documented
items.notes: test_harness.py created and run. Euler baseline after 1 orbit: position error 4.2e-2, energy error 1.7e-2 (secular drift). Results saved to results/euler_baseline.json.

items.description: Implement Velocity Verlet (Störmer-Verlet) symplectic integrator
items.acceptance_criteria: Function implementing the Velocity Verlet algorithm: x(t+dt) = x(t) + v(t)*dt + 0.5*a(t)*dt^2, v(t+dt) = v(t) + 0.5*(a(t)+a(t+dt))*dt. Same test harness as item_011 executed; relative energy error after 1 orbit is at least 100x smaller than Forward Euler at same dt. Results saved to results/ directory

items.description: Implement Leapfrog integration and compare with Velocity Verlet
items.acceptance_criteria: Function implementing kick-drift-kick Leapfrog: v(t+dt/2) = v(t) + a(t)*dt/2, x(t+dt) = x(t) + v(t+dt/2)*dt, v(t+dt) = v(t+dt/2) + a(t+dt)*dt/2. Comparison table generated showing energy error for Euler, Verlet, and Leapfrog on the 2-body orbit test at identical dt. Results saved to results/

items.description: Implement adaptive time-stepping based on local acceleration magnitude
items.acceptance_criteria: Time step selection rule: dt = min(dt_max, eta * sqrt(epsilon / max(|a_i|))) where eta is a dimensionless accuracy parameter. Test on a highly eccentric (e=0.9) 2-body orbit. Compare energy conservation of adaptive vs. fixed time-step Verlet over 10 orbits. Adaptive version achieves comparable energy error with fewer total force evaluations (measured and reported)

items.description: Implement gravitational softening and analyze its effect on close encounters
items.acceptance_criteria: Softened potential: F = -G*m1*m2*r / (|r|^2 + eps^2)^(3/2). Test with 3 bodies in a close encounter scenario. Run with 3 different softening values (eps = 0.001, 0.01, 0.1) and measure: (1) maximum acceleration encountered, (2) energy conservation over the encounter, (3) trajectory divergence from eps=0.001 baseline. Results table and trajectory plots saved to results/ and figures/

items.description: Investigate minimal Barnes-Hut tree approximation for O(N log N) force computation
items.acceptance_criteria: Implementation of 2D quad-tree (or 3D oct-tree) with monopole approximation and opening angle parameter theta. For N=100 random bodies: (1) force error vs. direct summation measured as RMS relative error for theta = 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 1.0, (2) wall-clock speedup over direct summation measured for N = 100, 500, 1000. Results compared against Barnes & Hut (1986) expected O(N log N) scaling cited in sources.bib

items.description: Benchmark energy conservation across all integrators over long time spans
items.acceptance_criteria: Run circular 2-body orbit for 10,000 time steps with each integrator (Euler, Verlet, Leapfrog) at dt = 0.01. Record |dE/E0| at every 100th step. Generate energy drift plot (time vs. relative energy error) saved to figures/energy_drift.png. Euler shows linear drift, Verlet/Leapfrog show bounded oscillation — both behaviors quantified and compared against expected behavior from literature (cited in sources.bib)

items.description: Measure wall-clock performance scaling with particle count
items.acceptance_criteria: Timing benchmark for N = 10, 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000 particles, each run for 100 time steps using Velocity Verlet. Wall-clock time measured and recorded. Log-log plot of N vs. time saved to figures/scaling.png. Direct summation shows O(N^2) slope confirmed by linear regression on log-log data (R^2 > 0.95). If Barnes-Hut implemented, its scaling included on same plot

items.description: Run standard multi-body test cases: figure-8 three-body orbit and inner solar system
items.acceptance_criteria: Two test cases executed: (1) Chenciner-Montgomery figure-8 three-body orbit with initial conditions from literature — trajectory plot saved to figures/figure8.png, periodicity error measured after 1 period, (2) inner solar system (Sun + 4 planets) with real masses and orbital parameters — run for 1 Earth year, compare final planet positions against expected positions. Both tests reference initial conditions from sources.bib

items.description: Compare simulation accuracy and performance against results reported in prior work
items.acceptance_criteria: Comparison table in results/comparison_vs_literature.json containing: (1) energy conservation results vs. values reported in at least 2 cited papers for equivalent test problems, (2) performance scaling vs. theoretical complexity from literature. Discrepancies > 10% explained with identified causes. At least 3 entries from sources.bib directly referenced in the comparison

items.description: Generate trajectory visualizations for key simulation scenarios
items.acceptance_criteria: At least 3 visualization plots saved to figures/: (1) 2-body elliptical orbit trajectories, (2) 3-body figure-8 trajectories, (3) N=50 random cluster evolution snapshots at t=0, t=T/4, t=T/2, t=T. Each plot has labeled axes, title, and legend. Plots saved as PNG files at minimum 300 DPI resolution

items.description: Produce quantitative summary table of integrator performance characteristics
items.acceptance_criteria: File results/integrator_summary.json containing a table with columns: integrator name, order of accuracy, symplectic (yes/no), energy error after 10k steps (2-body test), wall-clock time per step (N=100), and recommended use case. All 3+ integrators included. Values are numeric (not qualitative) and reproducible from the experiment scripts

items.description: Write findings document with methodology, results, and conclusions
items.acceptance_criteria: File FINDINGS.md in repo root containing: (1) Introduction stating the problem and goals, (2) Methodology section describing each integrator and force computation method, (3) Results section with embedded references to figures/ and results/ outputs, (4) Discussion comparing findings to prior work cited in sources.bib (at least 5 citations referenced), (5) Conclusions with recommendations for which integrator to use and when. Minimum 500 words

items.description: Document codebase with module-level descriptions and usage examples
items.acceptance_criteria: Each source file has a module-level docstring/comment explaining its purpose. At least 3 inline comments on non-obvious algorithmic steps (e.g., softening, half-step velocity update). A USAGE section in README.md with: (1) installation/dependency instructions, (2) command to run the basic 2-body simulation, (3) command to run the full benchmark suite, (4) expected output description

items.description: Final README update with project overview, reproduction steps, and results summary
items.acceptance_criteria: README.md updated to contain: (1) project title and one-paragraph description, (2) list of implemented features (integrators, force methods), (3) key results summary (best energy conservation achieved, scaling behavior), (4) reproduction instructions (single command to regenerate all results and figures), (5) references section pointing to sources.bib. README is valid Markdown and renders correctly
